children.name: Police Power
children.enum1: Ericta definition - Froyn
children.enum2: Drilon definition

children.name: Two Legal Principles that Constitute as the Basis for Police Power
children.enum1: 1) Salus populi est supreme lex
children.enum2: 2) Sic utere tuo ut alienum non laedas - use your property as not to injure other property rights

children.name: Philippine Association of Service Exporters vs. Drilon
children.details: OFW
children.enum1: Police power has been defined as the 'state authority to enact legislation that may interfere with personal liberty or property in order to promote the general welfare.'
children.enum3: It finds no specific Constitutional grant for the plain reason that it does not owe its origin to the Charter. Along with the taxing power and eminent domain, it is inborn in the very fact of statehood and sovereignty.
children.enum4: The police power of the State is a power coextensive with self-protection, and it is not inaptly termed the 'law of overwhelming necessity.' It may be said to be that inherent and plenary power in the State which enables it to prohibit all things hurtful to the comfort, safety, and welfare of society.
children.enum5: Sic utere tuo ut alienum non laedas

children.name: Components of Police Power
children.enum1: (1) an imposition of restraint upon liberty or property,
children.enum2: (2) in order to foster the common good. It is not capable of an exact definition but has been, purposely, veiled in general terms to underscore its all comprehensive embrace.

children.name: Ichong vs. Hernandez
children.details: Retail Trade
children.enum1: Police power is the most positive and active of all governmental processes, the most essential, insistent and illimitable.
children.enum2: As we cannot foresee the needs and demands of public interest and welfare in this constantly changing and progressive world, so we cannot delimit beforehand the extent or scope of police power by which and through which the State seeks to attain or achieve public interest or welfare.
children.enum3: The State can deprive persons of life, liberty and property, provided there is due process of law; and persons may be classified into classes and groups, provided everyone is given the equal protection of the law. The test or standard, as always, is reason.

children.name: Characteristics of Police Power
children.enum1: 1. Most essential
children.enum2: 2. Insistent
children.enum3: 3. Illimitable - (but subject to the implied limitations of the Bill of Rights)

children.name: Lutz vs. Araneta
children.details: Sugar Industry
children.enum1: In the wide field of its police power, the lawmaking body could provide that the distribution of benefits therefrom be readjusted among its components to enable it to resist the added strain of the increase in taxes that it had to sustain.
children.enum2: If the law presumably hits the evil where it is most felt, it is not to be over-thrown because there are other instances to which it might have been applied.
children.enum3: Sugar production is one of the great industries of our nation, sugar occupying a leading position among its export products. Hence, it was competent for the legislature to find that the general welfare demanded that the sugar industry should be stabilized in turn.

children.name: Test for the Validity of Police Power
children.enum1: 1. Lawful subject - whether there is a the public interest involved that requires the interference of the State, AND
children.enum2: 2. Lawful means -

children.name: As to Taxation
children.details: Eminent domain cannot be used as an implement of police power due to its inherent incompatibilities, but it can be used as a complement.

children.name: Association of Small Landowners vs. Secretary of Agrarian Reform
children.enum1: Recent trends would indicate not a polarization but a mingling of the police power and the power of eminent domain, with the latter being used as an implement of the former like the power of taxation.
children.enum2: The general rule at least is that while property may be regulated to a certain extent, if regulation goes too far it will be recognized as a taking.
children.enum3: Restriction imposed to protect the public health, safety or morals from dangers threatened is not a taking. The restriction is merely the prohibition of a noxious use.
children.enum4: *This case demonstrates police power as a complement of eminent domain.
children.enum5: Justice Holmes: If the regulation goes to far, it is equivalent to taking (read back for exact quote)

children.name: Lozano vs. Martinez
children.details: BP 22
children.enum1: The effects of the issuance of a worthless check transcends the private interests of the parties directly involved in the transaction and touches the interests of the community at large. The mischief it creates is not only a wrong to the payee or holder, but also an injury to the public.
children.enum2: Police power is a dynamic force that enables the state to meet the exigencies of changing times. There are occasions when the police power of the state may even override a constitutional guaranty.

children.name: Department of Education, Culture and Sports vs. San Diego
children.details: NMAT
children.enum1: It is the right and indeed the responsibility of the State to insure that the medical profession is not infiltrated by incompetents to whom patients may unwarily entrust their lives and health.
children.enum2: The State has the responsibility to harness its human resources and to see to it that they are not dissipated or, no less worse, not used at all. These resources must be applied in a manner that will best promote the common good while also giving the individual a sense of satisfaction.

children.name: Ynot vs. Intermediate Appellate Court
children.details: Carabeef
children.enum1: To justify the State in thus interposing its authority in behalf of the public, it must appear, first, that the interests of the public generally, as distinguished from those of a particular class, require such interference; and second, that the means are reasonably necessary for the accomplishment of the purpose, and not unduly oppressive upon individuals.

children.name: US v. Toribio in relation to EO 626-A
children.enum1: There is no rational connection because the indiscriminate slaughtering is not prevented by inter-regional transfer of large cattle. Hence, the EO 626-A does not pass the lawful means test.

children.name: City Government of Quezon City vs. Ericta
children.details: Pauper Burial
children.enum1: In police power, the owner does not recover from the government for injury sustained in consequence thereof.
children.enum2: Police power does not involve the taking or confiscation of property with the exception of a few cases where there is a necessity to confiscate private property in order to destroy it for the purpose of protecting the peace and order and of promoting the general welfare.
children.enum3: The purpose in police power is the destruction of the noxious property

children.name: Manila Memorial Park vs. Secretary of DSWD
children.details: Senior Citizen Discount
children.enum1: Under the police power of the State, property rights of individuals may be subjected to restraints and burdens in order to fulfill the objectives of the government.
children.enum2: Because of the exigencies of rapidly changing times, Congress may be compelled to adopt or experiment with different measures to promote the general welfare which may not fall squarely within the traditionally recognized categories of police power and eminent domain.
children.enum3: The subject regulation may be said to be similar to, but with substantial distinctions from, price control or rate of return on investment control laws which are traditionally regarded as police power measures.
children.enum4: The time-honored rule is that the burden of proving the unconstitutionality of a law rests upon the one assailing it and “the burden becomes heavier when police power is at issue.”

children.details: Is there a taking in the amendment of the Senior Citizen discount?
children.enum1: The establishments only have an inchoate right on the amount of the discount, and therefore it is not a taking since such it is not yet part of the profits. The law only regulates profit of the establishments.

children.name: Mosqueda vs. Pilipino Banana Growers & Exporters Association
As to the 30 meter buffer zone
children.details: The maintenance of the zone wherein the owners can only plant tall trees is merely a regulation akin to changing the land usage classification of the property. Therefore, the owners are not entitled to just compensation since there is no taking in the exercise of the power of eminent domain.

children.name: The rational relation test or rational basis test
children.details: The rational basis scrutiny demands that the classification reasonably relate to the legislative purpose. The rational basis test often applies in cases involving economics or social welfare, or to any other case not involving a suspect class.

children.name: Special Requirements as to LGUs for the Exercise of the Delegated Police Power
children.enum1: 1. formal requirement
children.enum2: 2. substantive requirement

children.name: Formal Requirement
children.enum1: 1. the ordinance is enacted within the corporate powers of the local government unit
children.enum2: 2. it is passed in accordance with the procedure prescribed by law

children.name: Substantive Requirements
children.enum1: 1. conformity of the ordinance with the limitations under the Constitution and the statutes
children.enum2: 2. it must be fair, not oppressive
children.enum3: 3. it must not be partial or discriminatory
children.enum4: 4. it must not prohibit but may regulate trade
children.enum5: 5. it must be general and consistent with public policy

children.name: City of Manila vs. Chinese Community of Manila
children.details: Chinese Cemetery
children.enum1: If the legislature should grant the expropriation of a certain or particular parcel of land for some specified public purpose, the courts would be without jurisdiction to inquire into the purpose of that legislation.
children.enum2: If the Legislature should grant general authority to a municipal corporation to expropriate private land for public purposes, the courts have ample authority to make inquiry and to hear proof, upon an issue properly presented, concerning whether or not the lands were private and whether the purpose was, in fact, public.
children.enum3: The right of expropriation is not an inherent power in a municipal corporation, and before it can exercise the right some law must exist conferring the power upon it.
children.enum4: The legislature, in providing for the exercise of the power of eminent domain, may directly determine the necessity for appropriating private property for a particular improvement for public use, and 'it may select the exact location of the improvement.
children.enum5: When the statute does not designate the property to be taken nor how much may be taken, then the necessity of taking particular property is a question for the courts.

children.name: Validity of Expropriation
children.details: When the courts come to determine the question, they must not only find
children.enum1: (1) that a law or authority exists for the exercise of the right of eminent domain, but
children.enum2: (2) also that the right or authority is being exercised in accordance with the law.

children.name: Republic vs. Philippine Long Distance Telephone Co.
children.details: Exprorpiation of Services
children.enum1: No cogent reason appears why the power of eminent domain may not be availed of to impose only a burden upon the owner of condemned property, without loss of title and possession.
children.enum2: If, under section 6, Article XIII, of the Constitution, the State may, in the interest of national welfare, transfer utilities to public ownership uponpayment of just compensation, there is no reason why the State may not require a public utility to render services in the general interest, provided just compensation is paid therefor.
children.enum3: While the Republic may not compel the PLDT to celebrate a contract with it, the Republic may, in the exercise of the sovereign power of eminent domain, require the telephone company to permit interconnection of the government telephone system and that of the PLDT, as the needs of the government service may require, subject to the payment of just compensation to be determined by the court.

children.name: People vs. Fajardo
children.details: Public Plaza
children.enum1: The State may not, under the guise of police power, permanently divest owners of the beneficial use of their property and practically confiscate them solely to preserve or assure the aesthetic appearance of the community.
children.enum2: An ordinance which permanently so restricts the use of property that it cannot be used for any reasonable purpose goes beyond regulation and must be recognized as a taking of the property.
children.enum3: Restriction leaves the owner subject to the burden of payment of taxation, while outright confiscation would relieve him of that burden.

children.name: Republic vs. Vda. De Castellvi
children.enum1: When the taking of the property sought to be expropriated coincides with the commencement of the expropriation proceedings, or takes place subsequent to the filing of the complaint for eminent domain, the just compensation should be determined as of the date of the filing of the complaint.
children.enum2: In expropriation proceedings, the owner of the land has the right to its value for the use for which it would bring the most in the market.
children.enum3: The report of the commissioners of appraisal in condemnation proceedings are not binding, but merely advisory in character, as far as the court is concerned.

children.name: Elements of Taking
children.details: Taking under the power of eminent domain may be defined generally as:
children.enum1: (1) Entering upon private property;
children.enum2: (2) For more than a momentary period;
children.enum3: (3) Under the warrant or color of legal authority;
children.enum4: (4) Devoting it to a public use; or
children.enum5: (5) Otherwise informally appropriating or injuriously affecting it in such a way as substantially to oust the owner and deprive him of all beneficial enjoyment thereof.

children.name: Amigable vs. Cuenca
children.details: Expropriation without Just Compensation
children.enum1: Where the government takes away property from a private landowner for public use without going through the legal process of expropriation or negotiated sale, the aggrieved party may properly maintain a suit against the government without thereby violating the doctrine of governmental immunity from suit without its consent.

children.name: Philippine Press Institute vs. COMELEC
children.details: COMELEC Space
children.enum1: To compel print media companies to donate “Comelec space” amounts to “taking” of private personal property for public use or purposes.
children.enum2: The requisites for a lawful taking of private property for public use: the necessity for the taking and legal authority to effect the taking.

children.name: Sumulong vs. Guerrero
children.details: Socialized Housing
children.enum1: At present, whatever may be beneficially employed for the general welfare satisfies the requirement of public use.
children.enum2: The propriety of exercising the power of eminent domain cannot be determined on a purely quantitative or area basis.
children.enum3: The property owner may not interpose objections merely because in their judgment some other property would have been more suitable, or just as suitable, for the purpose.
children.enum4: Just compensation means a fair and full equivalent for the loss sustained. All the facts as to the condition of the property and its surroundings, its improvements and capabilities, should be considered.

children.name: Manosca vs. Court of Appeals
children.details: Manalo's Birthplace
children.enum1: Eminent domain is generally so described as “the highest and most exact idea of property remaining in the government” that may be acquired for some public purpose through a method in the nature of a forced purchase by the State.
children.enum2: Public use, in constitutional provisions restricting the exercise of the right to take private property in virtue of eminent domain, means a use concerning the whole community as distinguished from particular individuals. But each and every member of society need not be equally interested in such use, or be personally and directly affected by it; if the object is to satisfy a great public want or exigency, that is sufficient.
children.enum3: That only a few would actually benefit from the expropriation of property does not necessarily diminish the essence and character of public use.

children.name: EPZA vs. Dulay
children.details: Appointment of Not More than 3 Commissioners
children.enum1: Where the Court simply follows PD 1533, thereby limiting the determination of just compensation on the value declared by the owner or administrator or as determined by the Assessor, whichever is lower, it may result in the deprivation of the landowner's right of due process to enable it to prove its claim to just compensation, as mandated by the Constitution.
children.enum2: The determination of 'just compensation' in eminent domain cases is a judicial function. The executive department or the legislature may make the initial determinations but when a party claims a violation of the guarantee in the Bill of Rights that private property may not be taken for public use without just compensation, no statute, decree, or executive order can mandate that its own determination shall prevail over the court's findings.

children.name: Municipality of Parañaque vs. V.M. Realty Corp.
children.details: LGU Expropriation
children.enum1: An LGU may exercise the power to expropriate private property only when authorized by Congress and subject to the latter’s control and restraints, imposed through the law conferring the power or in other legislations.
children.enum2: A municipal ordinance is different from a resolution. An ordinance is a law, but a resolution is merely a declaration of the sentiment or opinion of a lawmaking body on a specific matter. An ordinance possesses a general and permanent character, but a resolution is temporary in nature.

children.name: Requisites for LGUs to exercise the power of expropriation
children.details: The following essential requisites must concur before an LGU can exercise the power of eminent domain:
children.enum1: (1) An ordinance is enacted by the local legislative council authorizing the local chief executive, in behalf of the LGU, to exercise the power of eminent domain over a particular private property;
children.enum2: (2) It is exercised for public use, purpose or welfare, or for the benefit of the poor and the landless;
children.enum3: (3) There is payment of just compensation; and
children.enum4: (4) A valid and definite offer has been previously made to the owner of the property sought to be expropriated, but said offer was not accepted.

children.name: Republic vs. Lim
children.details: 57 Years
children.enum1: When the state wields its power of eminent domain, there arises a correlative obligation on its part to pay the owner of the expropriated property a just compensation. If it fails, there is a clear case of injustice that must be redressed.
children.enum2: Just compensation embraces not only the correct determination of the amount to be paid to the owners of the land, but also the payment for the land within a reasonable time from its taking. Without prompt payment, compensation cannot be considered ‘just.’
children.enum3: Where an entry to the expropriated property precedes the payment of compensation, it has been held that if the compensation is not paid in a reasonable time, the party may be treated as a trespasser ab initio.
children.enum4: Expropriation of lands consists of two stages: the first is concerned with the determination of the authority of the plaintiff to exercise the power of eminent domain and the propriety of its exercise. The second phase is concerned with the determination by the court of “the just compensation for the property sought to be taken.” It is only upon the completion of these two stages that expropriation is said to have been completed.
children.enum5: Recovery of possession may be had when property has been wrongfully taken or is wrongfully retained by one claiming to act under the power of eminent domain or where a rightful entry is made and the party condemning refuses to pay the compensation which has been assessed or agreed upon; or fails or refuses to have the compensation assessed and paid.
children.enum6: In cases where the government failed to pay just compensation within 5 years from the finality of the judgment in the expropriation proceedings, the owners concerned shall have the right to recover possession of their property.

children.name: Sec. 9, Article III, 1987 Constitution
children.enum1: SECTION 9. Private property shall not be taken for public use without just compensation.

children.name: Sison vs. Ancheta
children.details: Compensation Income
children.enum1: Where the assailed tax measure is beyond the jurisdiction of the state, or is not for a public purpose, or, in case of a retroactive statute is so harsh and unreasonable, it is subject to attack on due process grounds.
children.enum2: The rule of uniformity does not call for perfect uniformity or perfect equality, because this is hardly attainable. Equality and uniformity in taxation means that all taxable articles or kinds of property of the same class shall be taxed at the same rate.
children.enum3: The taxing power has the authority to make reasonable and natural classifications for purposes of taxation.

children.name: Pascual vs. Secretary of Public Works
children.details: Private Property
children.enum1: The right of the legislature to appropriate funds is correlative with its right to tax, and, under constitutional provisions against taxation except for public purposes and prohibiting the collection of a tax for one purpose and the devotion thereof to another purpose, no appropriation of state funds can be made for other than a public purpose.
children.enum2: Incidental advantage to the public or to the state, which results from the promotion of private interests and the prosperity of private enterprises or business, does not justify their aid by the use of public money.

children.name: Punsalan vs. Municipal Board of Manila
children.details: Double Taxation
children.enum1: The Legislature may, in its discretion, select what occupations shall be taxed, and in the exercise of that discretion it may tax all, or it may select for taxation certain classes and leave the others untaxed.
children.enum2: The argument against double taxation may not be invoked where one tax is imposed by the state and the other is imposed by the city.

children.name: Lladoc vs. Commissioner of Internal Revenue
children.details: Donor's Tax
children.enum1: It is a cardinal rule in taxation that exemptions from payment thereof are highly disfavored by law, and the party claiming exemption must justify his claim by a clear, positive, or express grant of such privilege by law.
children.enum2: Section 22(3), Art. VI of the Constitution of the Philippines, exempts from taxation cemeteries, churches and parsonages or convents, appurtenant thereto, and all lands, buildings, and improvements used exclusively for religious purposes. The exemption is only from the payment of taxes assessed on such properties enumerated, as property taxes, as contradistinguished from excise taxes.
children.enum3: The phrase “exempt from taxation,” as employed in the Constitution should not be interpreted to mean exemption from all kinds of taxes.

children.name: Abra Valley College vs. Aquino
children.details: Living Quarters
children.enum1: The exemption in favor of property used exclusively for charitable or educational purposes is ‘not limited to property actually indispensable’ therefor, but extends to facilities which are incidental to and reasonably necessary for the accomplishment of said purposes.
children.enum2: The test of exemption from taxation is the use of the property for purposes mentioned in the Constitution.
children.enum3: The use of the school building or lot for commercial purposes is neither contemplated by law, nor by jurisprudence.

children.name: Sec. 28, Article VI, 1987 Constitution
children.enum1: (1) The rule of taxation shall be uniform and equitable. The Congress shall evolve a progressive system of taxation.
children.enum2: (2) The Congress may, by law, authorize the President to fix within specified limits, and subject to such limitations and restrictions as it may impose, tariff rates, import and export quotas, tonnage and wharfage dues, and other duties or imposts within the framework of the national development program of the Government.
children.enum3: (3) Charitable institutions, churches and parsonages or convents appurtenant thereto, mosques, non-profit cemeteries, and all lands, buildings, and improvements, actually, directly, and exclusively used for religious, charitable, or educational purposes shall be exempt from taxation.
children.enum4: (4) No law granting any tax exemption shall be passed without the concurrence of a majority of all the Members of the Congress.

children.name: Sec. 4 (3), Article XIV, 1987 Constitution
children.enum1: (3) All revenues and assets of non-stock, non-profit educational institutions used actually, directly, and exclusively for educational purposes shall be exempt from taxes and duties. Upon the dissolution or cessation of the corporate existence of such institutions, their assets shall be disposed of in the manner provided by law.
children.enum2: Proprietary educational institutions, including those cooperatively owned, may likewise be entitled to such exemptions subject to the limitations provided by law including restrictions on dividends and provisions for reinvestment.

children.name: United States vs. Ang Tang Ho
Article XI - Accountability of Public Officers
